summary.text_en: In his foundational paper 'Memoir on the Motive Power of Heat', French engineer Ã‰mile Clapeyron was the first to combine the two great gas lawsâ€”Boyle's Law (V âˆ 1/P) and Charles's/Gay-Lussac's Law (V âˆ T)â€”into a single, powerful equation. This equation (later refined by Clausius as PV = nRT), known as the 'Ideal Gas Law', perfectly describes the macroscopic relationship between Pressure (P), Volume (V), and Temperature (T) for an 'ideal' gas.

story.text_en: Before Clapeyron, the gas laws were separate: Boyle (`boyle_law_1662`) related P and V; Charles (`charles_law_1787`) related V and T. Clapeyron was building on the genius ideas of the late Sadi Carnot on heat engines. To put Carnot's theory into mathematical form, Clapeyron *needed* an equation that handled P, V, and T all at once. He skillfully 'glued' the two laws together to create this 'Equation of State'. His original form was PV = k(t + 267), showing he was already incredibly close to the concept of Absolute Zero (-273.15Â°C).

fun_facts.text_en: Clapeyron was a railway engineer. His interest in the gas laws was driven by a very practical problem: how to make 'steam engines' more efficient.
His paper also introduced the 'P-V diagram' (Clapeyron diagram) to visualize the 'Carnot cycle' of a heat engine, which is still the standard tool for teaching thermodynamics.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine a balloon. Boyle's Law tells you: if you *squeeze* it (Pressure up), it *shrinks* (Volume down). Charles's Law tells you: if you *heat* it (Temperature up), it *expands* (Volume up).
Clapeyron's 'Ideal Gas Law' (PV=nRT) was the first 'master equation' that put *all* of those factors together. It's like a 'gas calculator' that tells you exactly what happens if you squeeze the balloon *and* heat it at the same time.

applications.text_en: The design and efficiency analysis of all heat engines (internal combustion, steam turbines) begins with the Ideal Gas Law.

impact.text_en: The Ideal Gas Law is one of the cornerstones of 19th-century physics and chemistry. It unified three separate, empirical laws (Boyle, Charles, Gay-Lussac) into a single, concise mathematical equation. Beyond its immense practical use, it provided the mathematical foundation for the new sciences of 'Thermodynamics' (the study of heat and work) and 'Statistical Mechanics' (the study of *how* atoms create P, V, and T).

influenced_by.contribution_en: Sadi Carnot (whose theory of heat engine efficiency was Clapeyron's direct inspiration)

influenced.contribution_en: Rudolf Clausius (who refined the Ideal Gas Law and used it to formulate the Second Law of Thermodynamics)
Boltzmann (one of the grand goals of his 'Statistical Mechanics' was to explain *why* PV=nRT works on a microscopic level)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Clapeyron's equation unified three separate laws into one powerful 'Equation of State', transforming the study of gases from experimental physics into a mature theoretical science.
